description: Five people were shot at a morning practice about five miles from the Capitol, the police said.
title: What Happened at the Shooting at a Congressional Baseball Practice
title_page: What Happened at the Shooting at a Congressional Baseball Practice - The New York Times
maintext:
Representative Steve Scalise, Republican of Louisiana and the House majority whip, was among several people shot on Wednesday morning when a gunman opened fire at a baseball field where congressional Republicans were practicing. Here is what is known so far:
East Monroe Ave. Gunshots broke windows at the Y.M.C.A. building. The gunman fired from behind a fence between home plate and the third-base dugout. Capitol Police vehicles were parked behind the dugout. 3rd Senator Jeff Flake and others took cover in the first-base dugout. 1st Rep. The police said a call came in at 7:09 a.m., and officers responded in three minutes. Two officers engaged the gunman and returned fire, according to the authorities.
At least four people were wounded and taken to the hospital, the police said:

Mr. Brooks told CNN that players took cover wherever they could on the field and that members of a security team exchanged fire with the gunman, who had a rifle.
After the shooting stopped, members rushed to the aid of Mr. Scalise.
Representative Roger Williams, Republican of Texas, was wheeled away by emergency medical service personnel at the park. Alex Wong/Getty Images
The Republicans were practicing at a park in Alexandria, Va., a suburb of Washington, for an annual charity baseball game against their Democratic counterparts scheduled for Thursday.
The suspect, James Thomas Hodgkinson, 66, of Belleville, Ill., died in a Washington hospital after the shootout. His brother said Wednesday that Mr. Hodgkinson had been distraught over the election of President Trump and had traveled to Washington in recent weeks to protest.
